content:
The "Hunger-Free Communities Act of 2007" includes sections on short title, table of contents, findings, definitions, national commitment to end hunger, and strengthening community efforts through collaborative grants, infrastructure grants, training, and technical assistance grants. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Congress finds that at the 1996 World Food Summit, the United States pledged to reduce undernourishment by half by 2015. The Department of Health and Human Services adopted the Healthy People 2010 goal to cut food insecurity in half by 2010. National nutrition programs are efficient in preventing hunger and improving nutrition. In 2001, food banks and community organizations helped feed over 23 million low-income individuals. The curr_chunk highlights the important roles that community organizations play in addressing hunger, such as measuring food security, developing plans for improvement, educating leaders, implementing nutrition programs effectively, and connecting food insecure individuals to anti-hunger programs. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions include terms like domestic hunger goal, emergency feeding organization, food security, and hunger-free communities goal. The term "Secretary" in H. Con. Res. 302 (102nd Congress) refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. TITLE I--NATIONAL COMMITMENT TO END HUNGER

SEC. 101. HUNGER REPORTS. The Secretary shall conduct a study on hunger in the United States within 1 year of this Act and update it every 5 years. The study will assess data on hunger and food insecurity, as well as measures taken by governments to address the issue. The Secretary will develop recommendations to remove obstacles and reduce domestic hunger, submitting a report to the President and Congress within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The Act requires a report with detailed study results and Secretary's recommendations to be submitted within 5 years, along with an update of the report. TITLE II--STRENGTHENING COMMUNITY EFFORTS

SEC. 121. HUNGER-FREE COMMUNITIES COLLABORATIVE GRANTS. Title II of the document focuses on strengthening community efforts, specifically through the Hunger-Free Communities Collaborative Grants. Eligible entities, such as public food program service providers or nonprofit organizations, can receive grants to achieve hunger-free communities goals. The Secretary can allocate up to 50% of funds for these grants, with the Federal share not exceeding 80% of the costs. Non-Federal organizations must also contribute a share of the costs. The non-Federal share of the cost for activities can be provided in cash or in kind, including facilities, equipment, or services. Any entity can contribute the non-Federal share through a State government, local government, or private source. To apply for a grant under this section, eligible entities must submit an application to the Secretary, identifying the activities the grant will fund. To apply for a grant, eligible entities must submit an application to the Secretary, detailing how the grant will be used to reduce hunger in the community. They must also list partner organizations involved, describe any necessary agreements, and provide a summary of any assessments performed. Priority for grants under this section is given to eligible entities that demonstrate collaborative efforts to reduce hunger in their community, particularly in rural or underserved areas with high rates of food insecurity, poverty, or unemployment. Evidence of long-term hunger reduction efforts and public support are also considered. An eligible entity can use grant funds to assess hunger in the community, including analyzing the issue and evaluating facilities and equipment for achieving a hunger-free goal. An eligible entity can use grant funds to assess hunger in the community, including analyzing the effectiveness of existing nutrition programs and emergency feeding organizations, and creating a plan to achieve hunger-free communities goals. Grant funds can also be used for distributing food to meet the immediate needs of people experiencing hunger in the community. The curr_chunk focuses on reducing hunger in the community through distributing food, providing outreach, improving access to food, developing new resources, and establishing programs for hunger-free communities. The curr_chunk focuses on establishing a program to provide food and nutrition services as part of a coordinated community-based comprehensive service. Establishing a program for hunger-free communities infrastructure grants. The term "eligible entity" refers to emergency feeding organizations. The Secretary can allocate up to 40% of funds to make grants for activities, with the Federal share not exceeding 80%. Eligible entities must submit an application to receive a grant. Each grant application must identify activities to reduce hunger in the community. Priority is given to entities serving rural or underserved areas with high rates of food insecurity, poverty, or unemployment. An eligible entity receiving a grant must use the funds to support hunger relief agencies by constructing, expanding, or repairing facilities. Priority is given to entities serving communities with high rates of food insecurity, poverty, or unemployment. The entity must also demonstrate a commitment to achieving hunger-free communities goals. The grant funds must be used to support hunger relief agencies by assisting in obtaining locally-produced produce and protein products, as well as processing and serving wild game. SEC. 123. HUNGER-FREE COMMUNITIES TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The term "eligible entity" refers to a nonprofit organization that carries out specific activities. The Secretary can allocate up to 10% of funds for grants to cover 80% of costs for these activities. To apply for a grant, the eligible entity must submit an application with required information to the Secretary. Each application submitted by an eligible nonprofit entity must demonstrate non-profit status, detail training and technical assistance programs, and describe how they work towards domestic hunger and hunger-free communities goals. The Secretary gives priority to eligible entities serving rural or underserved areas, regions with high rates of food insecurity or poverty, regions with long-term hunger reduction efforts, or regions with grants under sections 121 or 122. An eligible entity receiving a grant must use the funds for national or regional training and technical assistance for organizations working towards domestic hunger or hunger-free communities goals. The entity must serve a region that supports its efforts and is committed to achieving multiple hunger-free communities goals. SEC. 124. REPORT.

The Secretary must submit a report to Congress by September 30, 2013, detailing each grant made under this title, including activities funded and their success in achieving hunger-free communities goals. The report should also assess the overall success of activities funded by grants in achieving domestic hunger goals.

SEC. 125. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

$50,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually for fiscal years 2008 through 2013 to implement this title.
